Award.AwardTitle: CSEDI Collaborative Research: Next Generation Modeling of Core Turbulence via Combined Laboratory, Numerical and Theoretical Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
The geomagnetic field is generated by a so-called `fluid dynamo'. This dynamo is driven by rapidly rotating, turbulent convection in Earth's molten metal core. Yet rapidly rotating core-style convective turbulence has not been accurately simulated. The goal of this project is to provide the first cross-disciplinary quantification of rapidly rotating, turbulent, core-style convection. In doing so, we will greatly strengthen our understanding of the core flows that turn Earth into a giant magnet.

We will develop next-generation models of turbulent convection in Earth's core to address significant limitations in current models of dynamo generation. These models will combine leading laboratory rotating convection experiments with state-of-the-art finite element models and with advanced, asymptotically reduced theoretical models of rotating convection systems. The data we will produce will be of fundamental importance to modelers of Earth's core and other planetary dynamos, as well as modelers of solar and stellar convection zones and dynamos, and modelers of Earth's climate and planetary atmospheres. The asymptotically reduced modeling tools will be made openly available through the Computational Infrastructure for Geosciences (CIG) website. Furthermore, we will develop a unique library of geoscience educational films, via an ongoing internship for students interested in combining science and documentary filmmaking.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to the mechanical limitations of laboratory experiments and the resolution limitations of numerical simulations, a comprehensive probe of the turbulence of the Earth's liquid outer core remains challenging. This is the region where the Earth's magnetic field is generated and the seed of its evolution on geological timescales. New modeling approaches that capture dyamics of primary importance are required. This is accomplished in this project which utilizes an advanced methodology in the mathematics - called asymptotics - to rigorously extract simplier models from the master fluid equations used extensively in the sciences. 

The model takes advantage of the dominant balance between rotational and pressure gradient forces  that persist in the Earth's outer core - this is known as the geostrophic balance. The new model was then used in a study of idealized setting for the outer core - a layer of fluid heated from below and cooled from above undergoing rapid rotation. The effort included a synergistic compnent  that also included laboratory experiments and numerical simulations of the master fluid equations. The new model was validated by simulations and experiments in an overlapping regimes of parameter space. The asymptotic model was then investigated in regimes of parameter space unobtainable by numerical simulations and laboratory experiments. 

Simulations using reduced asymptotic models, specifically, the NonHy- drostatic QuasiGeostrophic Model (NH-QGM) have established the existence of four distinct flow morphologies of increasing complexity obtained as a function of increasing reduced Rayleigh num- ber RaE4/3 - the cellular, convective Taylor column, plume and geostrophic turbulence regimes (See Figures). The transition between each regime was found to be detectable in global heat transport measurements. These findings enabled laboratory and DNS data obtained in the rapidly rotating limit to be characterized and understood. 

Geostrophic turbulence is the most pertinent regime that characterizes the turbulent motions of planetary interiors. Simulations of this regime using the asymptotic model revealed for the first time a new nonlocal inverse cascade mechanism where small-scale geostrophic convective turbulence directly excites a domain filling turbulent dipole vortex pair that spans the depth of the fluid layer. The existence of the inverse cascade has also been confirmed by numerical simulation of the master fluid equations. The new inverse cascade mechanism offers an alternative explanation of how columnar structures associated with satellite observations of  dipolar magnetic field anomalies may form on planetary scales. In Julien et al. (2012b) we also establish that a geostrophic turbulent interior acts as the thermal bottleneck of the efficient of heat streaming though the bounded layer.- a result that has thus far alluded the non-rotating convection community where the laminar layers close to domain boundaries  are identified as the thermal bottleneck.

The synergistic investigation of thernally forced rotating fluid turbulence also revealed the remarkable result that vanishingly thin viscous boundary layers at the domain boundaries are capable of transporting large amounts of heat. This has important implications for future models that try to capture turbulence of planetary interiors in a more detailed fashion (for instance in sphercial domains).
